channel.title: Java Mentoring
channel.description:
I'm looking for someone that can help me with learning Java. I have basic knowledge of how Java works and I'm interested in making a server. I can do simple things on Java but when I look at normal server files, I don't really understand what's going on. I bought "Java For Dummys" and I'm half way done but I still need to know how Java works for Runescape.
Basically I wish to make a server that is completely original. I will be creating original weapons, armor and NPCs and I need to learn how to do these things. If anyone is willing to teach me, I will give 10% of all of my earnings to you. I expect around 7,500 membership payments over the course of a year.
If you are willing to help, please let me know.

item.title: Java Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Those are ALL client sided. Go look at some of the client hacking tutorials & model section tutorials

Read full topic

item.title: Java Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @Lazyness Lazyness
item.description:
@Lazyness wrote:

Well alright then.

Here is exactly what I need to know (I’m doing research but it would help if you told me here anyways):

How to add custom items to a server [Metasequoia]
How to add custom armor to a server [Metasequoia]

Also I have loads of questions on how Metasequoia works:

How to connect two or more vertices
How to make vertices connect to a face
How to get rid of lines/vertices that aren’t attached to faces

Yes I’m doing research but there aren’t a lot of tutorials on Metasequoia and I can’t really find a lot of relevant information.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Mentoring

item.description:

[quote=“Lazyness, post:51, topic:373913”]Why are you all arguing over whether or not Void is a datatype?

Read full topic

item.title: Java Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @J_a_v_a_a J a v a a
item.description:
@J_a_v_a_a wrote:

Sorry lazy.

I thought you were confused because of people talking about voids.

A void method is simply a method that doesn’t end up returning something.

public boolean returnBool() { return true; }

See that a method declared with a boolean return type can return a boolean datatype?

Whereas a void method …

public void returnVoid() { // funny right ... return void :) java humor return; }

Notice that it doesn’t actually return a datatype. The void return type specifies that it doesn’t return a datatype.

However, void methods are still useful in performing functions when you don’t need to return a value.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @Lazyness Lazyness
item.description:
@Lazyness wrote:

Why are you all arguing over whether or not Void is a datatype?

None of your posts are really helpful to me.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“J a v a a, post:49, topic:373913”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=469906.msg3438777#msg3438777 date=1292962532]
No one said a void was a datatype, we’re saying you can assign variables from inside one lol

From http://download.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/javaOO/returnvalue.html:

The data type of the return value must match the method’s declared return type;

Thank you for digging you own hole.
[/quote]

Lmao stop trying to insult me and learn something.

Since a void can’t return any type of data there is obviously no datatype associated with it.

You read that sentence wrong. They’re saying that when you declare a method you include a return type, the return type must match the datatype returned, if you want to return true the datatype is a boolean because a boolean stores a true or false value. Now again, since a void CAN’T return any type of data, it has no datatype associated with it.

To put this in perspective, can you perform any operators on a void?

Try adding two voids together, oh wait … they aren’t datatypes, it’s just a method return type.[/quote]I wasn’t talking about voids, please read my posts. I was talking about how dumb you are for saying return types aren’t data types

Read full topic

item.title: Java Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @J_a_v_a_a J a v a a
item.description:
@J_a_v_a_a wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:48, topic:373913”]No one said a void was a datatype, we’re saying you can assign variables from inside one lol

From http://download.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/javaOO/returnvalue.html:

The data type of the return value must match the method’s declared return type;

Thank you for digging you own hole.[/quote]

Lmao stop trying to insult me and learn something.

Since a void can’t return any type of data there is obviously no datatype associated with it.

You read that sentence wrong. They’re saying that when you declare a method you include a return type, the return type must match the datatype returned, if you want to return true the datatype is a boolean because a boolean stores a true or false value. Now again, since a void CAN’T return any type of data, it has no datatype associated with it.

To put this in perspective, can you perform any operators on a void?

Try adding two voids together, oh wait … they aren’t datatypes, it’s just a method return type.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @J_a_v_a_a J a v a a
item.description:
@J_a_v_a_a wrote:

David, because of your last post I’ve given up hope on this thread.

An int is a datatype, a boolean is a datatype, a String is a datatype. Because it stores data! You cannot assign ANY PIECE OF DATA TO A VOID.

void = 1;

void = true;

void = “Hello”;

It just doesn’t work. A void is not a datatype it is a return type.

http://download.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/javaOO/returnvalue.html

http://download.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/nutsandbolts/datatypes.html

Stfu and read.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“J a v a a, post:43, topic:373913”]Then go ahead and try to use void to store a variable. GOOD LUCK BRO.

Void indicates that a method has no return value, boolean used in the declaration of a method means that it returns a boolean datatype. But void doesn’t return a datatype. Void is a return type not a datatype.[/quote]public void storeVariable(Object c) { myVariable = (int)c; }
???

[quote=“J a v a a, post:45, topic:373913”]To make myself more clear, DATATYPE NAMES USED IN THE DECLARATION OF A METHOD ARE CALLED RETURN TYPES. They aren’t called datatypes. A datatype can be used to store a variable, which void CAN’T DO!!!

Do you get it now :)?

void != datatype … void == return type[/quote]Uhhhhh… a return type is still a data type

Read full topic

item.title: Java Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @k0_twin k0 twin
item.description:
@k0_twin wrote:

[quote=“J a v a a, post:41, topic:373913”]You’re confused …

What you’re talking about is a keyword not a datatype.

EDIT:

Or were you thinking of return type?[/quote]

No…

It was added during the transition between C and C++ because in C by default a function returned an integer data type. Some functions don’t return a value of any kind. Thus, the need to have a data type that indicates nothing is being returned.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @k0_twin k0 twin
item.description:
@k0_twin wrote:

[quote=“J a v a a, post:39, topic:373913”][quote author=k0 twin link=topic=469906.msg3438624#msg3438624 date=1292957485]

void is actually the lack of a return type. You can’t go and do some code like this - it won’t work:

void x = null;

Void is a data type that represents the lack of a data type. But it’s still a data type.
[/quote]

Void is NOT a datatype …[/quote]

Yes it is. It’s there to declare functions that have no return value. In other words a data type that represents “empty”

Read full topic

item.title: Java Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

[quote=“Graham, post:34, topic:373913”][quote author=k0 twin link=topic=469906.msg3436047#msg3436047 date=1292773608]

class = your .java files
void = process that does something
boolean = returns true or false
int = number

Why do lots of people seem to think that “void” is the word for method? It’s a data type. Also, you’re using the assignment operator instead of the equivalence operator when giving somebody tips on proper conventions. The irony…
[/quote]

void is actually the lack of a return type. You can’t go and do some code like this - it won’t work:

void x = null; [/quote]
Sorry, but I must ask this question (dumb or not). So by this statement do you mean a void can be anything except something that ends in “return;”?

I obviously didn’t understand this, because true and false is a boolean (and I am not correcting you as I know that you know what you mean); but I don’t know what you mean.

Read full topic

void x = null;

item.title: Java Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @Lazyness Lazyness
item.description:
@Lazyness wrote:

10% isn’t bad… It’s free money for helping someone out until they get the hang of it.

So I made some progress! I made 11 2D models for weapons and as soon as I learn how to make them into 3D renderings, I can add them to the game! I’m going to make 30-50 custom items (over the course of a week) and then I’ll be starting work with custom hairstyles as well as armor.
